data: Le iscrizioni datate della Sicilia paleocristiana
Antonio Ferrua, «Le iscrizioni datate della Sicilia paleocristiana», Kokalos 28–29 (1983 1982): 3–29
Fragment of a later Roman Latin inscription
Remains of two evenly spaced lines of Latin letters; use of double-dot interpuncts.

Regularly cut letters of moderate width module (rectangular but not narrow). Vertical strokes of A and N in line 2 do not fully join; A has broken bar. Interpuncts formed of double vertical drilled holes.
467 CE or 538 CE, depending on the consular identification (Ferrua)
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 2023-07-07

2in pace <quae> vixit ann(is)
3p(lus) m(i)n(us) L deposit(a) III Kal(endas)
4Decemb(res) F̣ḷ(avio) Ṣṭịḷịc̣ọ-
5ne cons(ule) se vivi conpa[ra-]
6[v]er[u]n[t]

l.2 quae
Three even and equal lines of text, carefully set out, with vacats above and below.

Orsi attributed it to the Norman period, Ferrua (1989) suggested the Saracen period due to the name Taric, and Manganaro suggests Gothic, each lowering the date therefore, which seems to belong in late antiquity, perhaps later 6th century CE, or earlier 7th century CE, dated by indiction (14th).
Ferrara, 1829, Storia di Catania sino alla fine del secolo XVIII
Manganaro, 1993, Greco nei pagi e latino nelle città della Sicilia romana tra I e VI sec. d.C.

l.3 reg., orig. univera | l.4 reg., orig. que
Four lines of Latin letters, with vacat below; the trace of a letter below line 3 respects the exact distances between the other lines. Text runs at a slightly offset angle to the two edges.
Thin v-cut with neat serfis, use of supralines, ligatures, and a fairly narrow module. Very regular letters in height. G has a detached hook.
Letter types, esp. the G, sugg. c. 200 CE (so Manganaro; Ferrua dates later)
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 2015-10-20
Manganaro, 1988, La Sicilia da Sesto Pompeo a Diocleziano
Manganaro, 1989, Iscrizioni Latine nuove e vecchie della Sicilia

[---] 1[---]. Seius Agat͡ho
2[---] LM n(ummum) · II semis de
3[---]ṃo die m(ensis) Ianuarii
4[---]. (vac.13)

l.3 superscript

Irregular letters, some of which are larger than the others (the Latin D, the Greek Β). In the Greek text, E, Θ (according to Ferrua's drawing), Ω are lunate, (Latin and Greek), A has a broken cross-bar, Ξ is cursive. 
                                From Ferrua's drawing, the abbreviation of ὑπατίᾳ is realized through a small superscript π above the υ.
The Greek inscription has the consular date of 455 CE. If, as Manganaro believes, the two inscriptions are not the Latin and the Greek version of the same epitaph, they are nevertheless contemporary.

10ρίου σ(εβαστῶν) · τὸ · ε´ ·
Six densely ordered lines of neat Greek letters; staurogram to left of lines 3-4.
Neatly v-cut Greek letters with minimal serifs and some extended strokes. Alpha is tending towards the cursive form. Lunate epsilon and sigma, uncial omega; mu tending to cursive.
Dated to the 25 January 402 CE, by the consulship of Vincentius of 401 (omitting his colleague, Fravitus).

The text fills the surface, within a simple incised border, with a fixed margin on the left, uneven margin on the right. The space below the text is filled by three staurograms.
Lunate epsilon, sigma and omega, cursive mu; use of supralines on numerals and some abbreviation marks. Manganaro does not record letter heights.
